awd_abstract_narration:
Chen
DMS-1008905

     The objective of this project is to provide a systematic
study of multi-phase transitions.  There are macroscopic free
boundary models, which are based on observable quantities and are
needed to deal with singularities due to topological changes of
free boundaries, and microscopic continuum models, derived at the
molecular level and (always) well-posed.  One goal of the project
is to derive critical information from continuum models for free
boundary models when the latter become indeterminate.  Another is
to develop new microscopic continuum models for phase transitions
among phases such as solid/liquid and different grains in a
polycrystalline material.  The main tools used here are theories
of partial differential equations, singular perturbations,
asymptotic expansions, complex analysis, bifurcation, center
manifolds, global analysis, dynamical systems, and geometric
measure.  From time to time, computer assistance is used to first
stimulate, then validate, and further extend theoretical
conclusions. 

     The investigator studies interfacial phenomena, which are
commonplace in nature and occur whenever there is a continuum
that can exist in at least two different phases and there is some
mechanism that generates a spatial separation of these phases. 
The spatial boundaries that separate these phases, referred to as
interfaces or free boundaries, evolve with time due to some
enforcement of transitions of phases from one to another.  A
typical two-phase transition is a solidification process of a
liquid.  A classical multi-phase transition arises from
evolutions of grains in a polycrystal where alignments of atoms
in different grains do not match at grain boundaries.  The growth
of a solid polycrystal from a liquid involves a two-phase
transition between liquid and solid and a multi-phase transition
among grains.  These phenomena motivate new theoretical
development in free boundary problems, systems of parabolic or
elliptic partial or ordinary differential equations, and
dynamical systems.  Insights gained from the project increase
connections between mathematicians and materials scientists.  New
models developed here provide scientists with tools for
understanding and designing new materials.

por.por_cntn:
This project carried out research on interfacial dynamics, e.g., the motion of boundary between liquid and solid. Significant results are obtained and are published in 26 papers in high quality journals.

Two free boundary models are proposed and mathematically analyzed. One for the motion of boundary between solid and liquid and one for the contact angle at the intersection of vapor, liquid, and solid. For the first model, anisotropy (the mathematical base for the formation of snowflakes instead of ice balls) and long-range molecular interactions are considered. For the second model, the change of contact angles during the movement of liquid along solid surface with microscopic surface structure are considered. To analyze the models, advanced mathematical theories are developed and novel methods are introduced.

This project also developed a free boundary model for optimal investment and consumption with transaction cost. The free boundaries here are the price levels and amounts at which financial assets are sold or purchased. Mathematical theories are built for the model. Optimal strategies for the trading are described and analyzed.

Several classical free boundary problems proposed in the project are also investigated with significant results produced and published. New insights are obtained through the research. For the advancement of liquid front in a solidification process of undercooled liquid, a new method is introduced to produce a long anticipating result regarding the property of the liquid front. Also probabilistic models are introduced for phase changes, such as liquid and solid phase switch at freezing temperature.

The models proposed through the research provided new ingredients in the area of free boundary study. Mathematical theories developed greatly enhanced the power of mathematics. The novel methods introduced will be used for many existing open problems in the area of free boundary research.

Insight gained from the project greatly increased the connection between mathematics and its application. The research on investment and consumption provides a practitioner useful tool in evaluating financial situation and making rational decision. The new models developed from the project provide useful theoretical apparatus for scientists not specialized in mathematics to study the underling interfacial phenomena. They can be used to design new materials.

This project provided undergraduate and graduate students opportunities in conducting research using mathematical tools. Teaching materials are also developed from the research and are used in teaching undergraduate and graduate courses. These materials enhanced students' interests and their ability to solve real life problems using mathematics.

The research results are advocated through many national and international seminars, colloquiums, and conferences. These activities improved general public's appreciation of mathematics.
